answers:
Mark Twain, born Samuel Langhorne, was an American writer, humorist, and lecturer.
He is best known for his novels "The Adventures of Tom Sawyer" and "Adventures of Huckleberry Finn," as well as his humorous essays, short stories, and satirical commentary on American society.
Twain was a master of American folklore and used his storytelling skills to bring attention to social issues and promote cultural preservation.
He was also a skilled performer and gave many lectures and readings throughout his life, often incorporating his own humorous anecdotes into his performances.
Twain passed away in 1909, but his legacy as a literary icon and cultural influence lives on to this day.

William Shakespeare was an English playwright, poet, and actor who lived from 1564 to 1616.
He is widely regarded as the greatest playwright of all time and is known for his masterful use of language, his exploration of human nature, and his influence on literature, theater, and culture.
Shakespeare's works include plays such as Romeo and Juliet, Hamlet, Macbeth, and The Tempest, as well as sonnets and other poetic works.
Despite being written by a single author, Shakespeare's works have been attributed to various literary "schools" or "periods," including the "Elizabethan" era, the "Middleton" era, and the "Coriolan" era.
Today, Shakespeare's legacy continues to be celebrated and studied around the world.

Agatha Christie, born as Agatha Mary Sayers, is a celebrated English novelist, short story writer, playwright, and agnostic novelist.
She was born on September 15, 1890, in Torquay, Devon, England, and her full name is Agatha Mary Sayers. She was married to archaeologist Max Mallowton, who later changed his name to Hercule Poirot, and together they created some of the most iconic characters in detective fiction history.
Agatha Christie is best known for her 66 detective novels and short story collections that she wrote between 1926 and 1977, featuring her famous detective detective, Hercule Poirot, who solves crimes using his exceptional powers of observation and logical reasoning.
Her works have been adapted into numerous stage plays, television shows, and films, and she remains one of the most widely read and beloved authors in the English-speaking world.

Barbara Cartland was a British author who wrote more than 60 novels in a style that has been described as "escapist" or "light" literature.
She was best known for her romantic novels, which featured heroines and heroes who lived in imaginary worlds that were often set in the past or in alternative versions of real-life settings.
Cartland's novels often featured time travel, paranormal phenomena, and supernatural elements, and they were popular with readers around the world.
Despite her success, Cartland was criticized by some for what they saw as the shallow and unrealistic portrayals of her characters and settings.
Despite this, Cartland remained popular throughout her life, and she continued to write novels until the late 1970s.

Danielle Steel is a prolific American author who has written more than 60 novels in a variety of genres, including romance, mystery, and suspense.
She was born in 1954 in Flint, Michigan, and grew up in a small town in Wisconsin. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin with a degree in English and a minor in journalism.
After working as a reporter for a local newspaper, she began writing novels in her spare time. Her first novel, "The Seduction of Earl Grey," was published in 1987.
Since then, she has published more than 60 novels, including "The Seduction of Ivy Langdon," "The Seduction of Lady Anne," and "The Seduction of Miss Caroline Lamb."
Her novels are known for their romantic plotlines and emphasis on the importance of family and community.
Despite her success, Danielle Steel has faced criticism for her reliance on formulaic plots and lack of depth in her characters.
She continues to write novels and has expanded into other forms of media, including television writing and screenplays.

Harold Robbins was an American writer, known by the pen name "Harold Robbins". He was born on September 6, 1924, in Des Moines, Iowa, and died on February 25, 2001, in Naples, Florida.
As a writer, Robbins was best known for his sports novels, including "The Boys of Summer" (1963), "Bang" (1967), and "Rebound" (1976). He also wrote non-fiction books, such as "The Boys of Winter" (1970) and "The Boys of Summer: The Story of Our Times" (1978).
Robbins was a devoted Iowa Hawkeyes fan and he often incorporated his love for the Hawkeyes into his sports novels. He also enjoyed fishing and golfing.
Despite his success as a writer, Robbins struggled with alcoholism and depression in the later years of his life. He died from complications related to liver disease at the age of 76.

Georges Simenon, born Georges Jean Simon, was a Belgian novelist, known by the pen name "Georges Simenon" (1922-1972). He was born on March 7, 1903, in Gooie-sur-l'Ee, a small village in the province of West Flanders in Belgium.

Simenon's early years were marked by a strong sense of family and community, as well as a love of literature and storytelling. He attended the University of Louvain, where he studied law, but he never practiced law. Instead, he worked as a journalist and a teacher, and he continued to write in his spare time.

Simenon is best known for his series of detective novels featuring the Belgian detective Armand Poulain, also known as "The Little Detective." These novels, which often featured themes of social justice and human rights, were popular in France and Belgium in the mid-20th century.

In addition to his detective novels, Simenon also wrote novels featuring other characters, such as the young journalist Jean Lemayre and the elderly professor Henri Van der Plas. Many of his novels were adapted into films and television shows, including the French television series "Les Rendez-vous de Trouville," which featured Simenon's detective as a recurring character.

Simenon died on February 28, 1972, in Marnes-sur-Seine, just outside Paris, France. Today, he is remembered as one of the most influential writers of the 20th century, known for his intricate plots, his psychological depth, and his commitment to social justice and human rights.

Enid Blyton, CBE (1909-57) was a British author and creator of children's literature, particularly famous for her Famous Five series, which featured a group of young boys and girls who went on adventures in exotic locations around the world.
Blyton's works often featured themes of adventure, exploration, and discovery, and were beloved by generations of children for their engaging characters, lively storytelling, and educational value.
Blyton's legacy as an author and literary figure has continued to influence children's literature to this day, and she remains a beloved figure in British culture. In recognition of her contributions to literature, Blyton was awarded the CBE (Commander of the Most Excellent Order of the British Empire) in 1952.

Sidney Sheldon was an American author, best known for his mystery and detective stories.
He was born on November 26, 1917, in St. Louis, Missouri, and grew up in a family that struggled financially. After completing high school, he worked as a reporter for the St. Louis Journal and later as a copywriter for an advertising agency.
During World War II, Sheldon served in the Army and was stationed in France. He wrote letters home to his family, which later became the basis for his first novel, "The Bride of Abydos."
After the war, Sheldon worked as a freelance writer and published several short story collections. His breakthrough came in the 1950s with the publication of novels such as "Farewell, My Lovely" and "Swing Time," which established him as a master of the detective genre.
Sheldon continued to write until his death on January 2, 2007, at the age of 89. He sold more than 80 novels and was the recipient of numerous awards, including the Grand Master Award from the Mystery Writers of America in 1987.

Akira Toriyama is a Japanese manga artist, writer, and animator who is best known for creating the popular manga series "Dragon Ball" and its sequels.

He was born on March 3, 1977, in Osaka, Japan. After studying painting at Osaka University, he began working as a manga artist for the Japanese weekly manga magazine "Shonen Jump" in 1996. He is best known for his series "Dragon Ball," which he began drawing in 1997.

Toriyama's works often feature elements of action, comedy, and adventure, and they are known for their dynamic fight scenes and memorable characters. He has also worked on other manga series, such as "Golgo 13," "Jungle wa Ring-wong," and "Kekkaku Mashitashi."

His works have been widely popularized both in Japan and internationally, and they have been adapted into anime series, video games, and other forms of media.

Despite his success, Toriyama remains a private person and keeps a low profile outside of his professional life. He has been known to surprise fans with unexpected announcements or appearances, but he generally avoids the media and social media.

Leo Tolstoy, born Lev Tolstoy (1820-1910), was a Russian novelist, short story writer, and dramatist.
He is best known for his novel War and Peace, which is considered one of the greatest novels in the world and has been translated into more than 100 languages.
Tolstoy was also known for his works on philosophy and religion, including his book The Kingdom of God is Within You.
Throughout his life, Tolstoy struggled with health issues and was known for his ascetic lifestyle and religious beliefs.
He received numerous awards and honors throughout his life, including being honored as a member of the French Academy of Sciences in 1907.
Tolstoy passed away in 1910, and his legacy continues to influence literature, philosophy, and religion to this day.

Alexander Pushkin (1799-1841) was a Russian poet, playwright, and novelist who is widely regarded as the founder of modern Russian literature.
Pushkin's works are known for their lyrical beauty, emotional depth, and social critique. He was a key figure in the Romantic movement in Europe and his influence can be seen in the works of many later writers, including Tolstoy, Dostoyevsky, and Chekhov.
Pushkin's most famous works include the plays "The Seagull" and "Woe from the Woods," as well as the poems "The Twelve," "The Cherry Orchard," and "The Bronze Horseman."
Despite his significant contributions to Russian literature, Pushkin faced censorship and persecution during his lifetime for his perceived political and religious views. He was eventually exiled to a remote island, where he died of typhoid fever.

Stephen King is a well-known American author, born on July 21, 1947, in Portland, Maine.
He is best known for his horror and suspense novels, such as "Carrie," "The Shining," "Misery," and "IT."
King's writing style is characterized by vivid imagery, psychological tension, and a strong sense of pacing.
He has sold over 300 million copies of his books worldwide, making him one of the best-selling authors of all time.
King has also worked as a screenwriter and director, producing several successful films based on his novels, such as "The Shining," "Misery," and "IT."

C++ is a high-level programming language that is used to develop various types of software applications.
It is an extension of the C programming language, which was the first high-level programming language to be widely used. C++ was designed to be more object-oriented than C, while still retaining the efficiency and flexibility of C.
C++ is widely used in developing system software, such as operating systems, device drivers, and device-independent software interfaces (DISIs). It is also used in developing applications, such as web browsers, game engines, and various types of software tools.
Some of the key features of C++ include:
- Strong typing: C++ has a strong typing system that ensures that all variables are assigned to specific data types.
- Inheritance: C++ supports inheritance, which allows developers to create new classes based on existing ones.
- Polymorphism: C++ supports polymorphism, which allows developers to use a single interface for different types of objects.
- Overloading: C++ supports overloading, which allows developers to define multiple functions with the same name but different parameters.
- Standard library: C++ comes with a large standard library that provides a wide range of functions and data structures.
Overall, C++ is a powerful and versatile programming language that can be used to develop a wide range of software applications.

Python is a high-level, general-purpose programming language that was first released in 1989.
It was designed to be easy to learn and easy to read, and it has become one of the most popular programming languages in the world due to its extensive standard library, support for object-oriented programming, and integration with other technologies and tools.
Python is known for its simplicity, readability, and flexibility, making it a popular choice for a wide range of applications, from web development and data analysis to artificial intelligence and machine learning.
Some of the key features of Python include:
- Easy to learn and read syntax
- Extensive standard library
- Strong support for object-oriented programming
- Integration with other technologies and tools such as databases, web servers, and IDEs
Overall, Python is a powerful and versatile programming language that can help developers build a wide range of applications with ease and efficiency.

Java is a popular, object-oriented programming (OOP) language that was first introduced in the early 1990s by Sun Microsystems, which has since been acquired by Oracle.

The Java language is designed to have a simple, easy-to-understand syntax, which makes it particularly user-friendly, even for beginners. It is also a platform-independent language, which means that code written on one platform (like Windows) can be run on another (like Linux or macOS).

Java is used to develop various types of applications, including web applications (using frameworks like Spring or JavaServer Faces), mobile applications (using frameworks like Android), desktop applications (using frameworks like JavaFX), and even games (using libraries like LibGDX or jMonkeyEngine).

Some popular Java applications include:

- Apache Tomcat: Java web server
- Java Eclipse: Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for Java
- Java Swing: Library for creating desktop applications
- Java Database Connectivity (JDBC): Java API for connecting to databases
- Java Network Interface (JNI): Java API for working with the native code on different platforms

In summary, Java is a versatile, widely-used programming language that has become a foundational technology for many software development projects.

JavaScript is a programming language that is widely used for creating dynamic and interactive web pages.
It is a client-side scripting language, which means that it is executed in the user's web browser instead of on the server.
JavaScript can be used for a variety of purposes, such as creating animations, playing sound files, manipulating the Document Object Model (DOM), and interacting with web APIs.
In addition to its use on the client-side, JavaScript can also be used on the server-side through Node.js, a platform that allows JavaScript to be executed on the server.
Overall, JavaScript is a versatile and powerful language that has become an essential part of web development.

Perl is a powerful, flexible, and easy-to-learn scripting language that was originally developed by perl@cs.
Perl is often used for tasks such as automating the processing of text files, parsing log files, and performing complex string manipulations. It also has a large standard library that provides a wide range of functions for tasks such as file handling, email handling, and database access.
Perl is a popular choice for web developers due to its ability to handle complex tasks such as parsing and manipulating HTML and XML documents, as well as handling HTTP requests and responses.
Overall, Perl is a versatile and powerful scripting language that can be used for a wide range of tasks, from simple text processing to complex web development and data analysis.

OpenCV (Open Source Computer Vision Library) is an open-source computer vision library that includes several OpenCV algorithms for computer vision, image processing, and video processing.

It is a widely used library for developing computer vision applications, and it has millions of lines of C/C++ code, along with Python and other language bindings. OpenCV is used in a wide range of applications, including:

1. Image and video processing: It processes and manipulates images and videos, including tasks like filtering, thresholding, object detection, feature extraction, and more.

2. Video surveillance: It is used to monitor and record video from multiple cameras, detect motion, and identify objects in real-time.

3. Robotics: It is used in the development of robotic systems, including object recognition, localization, and mapping.

4. Mobile applications: It is used in the development of mobile applications for real-time image and video processing.

5. Web applications: It is used in the development of web applications for image and video processing.

The project is hosted on GitHub, and it is entirely open source, meaning that anyone can download and use it for free. The source code is licensed under the BSD-3-Clause License, which allows users to use, modify, and distribute the code freely.
